profileText: A Senator from Wisconsin; born in Hampton, N.Y., January 3, 1815; attended the common schools and Middlebury (Vt.) Academy, and graduated from Hobart College, Geneva, N.Y., in 1834; studied law; admitted to the bar in 1837 and commenced practice in Rochester, N.Y.; moved to Warsaw, N.Y., in 1841; district attorney of Wyoming County, N.Y., 1847-1850; moved to Racine, Wis., in 1851; judge of the first judicial circuit of Wisconsin 1853-1856, when he resigned; the repeal of the Missouri Compromise caused him to leave the Democratic Party; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in January 1857; reelected in 1863 and served from March 4, 1857, to March 3, 1869; chairman, Committee on Indian Affairs (Thirty-seventh through Thirty-ninth Congresses); left the Republican Party and was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor on the Democratic ticket in 1871; resumed the practice of law in Chicago, Ill., but retained his residence in Racine, Wis.; trustee of the University of Chicago, serving one year as its president, and was for many years a professor in its law school; died in Edgewood, Providence, R.I., July 23, 1897; interment in Mound Cemetery, Racine, Wis.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Albright, Claude. "Dixon, Doolittle and Norton: The Forgotten Republican Votes.'' Wisconsin Magazine of History 59 (Winter 1975-1976): 91-100.
Chaput, Donald. "Generals, Indian Agents, Politicans: The Doolittle Survey of 1865.'' Western Historical Quarterly 3 (July 1972): 269-82.

Doolittle, William Frederick, comp. The Doolittle Family in America. 8 vols. Cleveland: Press of National Printing Co., 1901-1967. Vol. 7 includes a brief biography of James Rood Doolittle, pp. 659-717.

Mowry, Duane, ed. "Letters of Carl Schurz, B. Gratz Brown, James S. Rollins, G.G. Vest et al., Missourians, from the Private Papers and Correspondence of Senator James Rood Doolittle of Wisconsin.'' Missouri Historical Review 11 (1916-1917): 1-20.

___, ed. [Excerpts from the James R. Doolittle Papers, various titles]. Publications of the Southern History Association 8 (January 1903): 57-60; (March 1904): 139-46; (May 1904): 212-18; (July 1904): 287-93; (September 1904): 367-72; (November 1904): 462-64; 9 (January 1905): 24-26; (May 1905): 174-82; (July 1905): 241-44; (November 1905): 401-10; 10 (March 1906): 96-100; (September 1906): 283-88; 11 (January 1907): 6-9; (March 1907): 94-105.
Sellers, James L. "James R. Doolittle.'' Wisconsin Magazine of History 17 (December 1933): 168-78; (March 1934): 277-306; (June 1934): 393-401; 18 (September 1934): 20-41; (December 1934): 178-87.

researchRecord.name: 1858-1927. 136 items. In part transcripts. Correspondence, speeches, and newspaper clippings related to matters concerning Doolittle during the Civil War and Reconstruction. Available on 1 microfilm reel. Finding aid.
February 12, 1865. 1 letter. From Samuel Jones Tilden.
March 21, 1858. 1 letter. From James Duane Doty.

1831-1897, 1935. 15 boxes. Correspondence, speeches, legal memorandum books, and scrapbooks. Topics include early political activities in New York state, family affairs in Racine, WI, the slavery controversy, the election of 1860, patronage, campaigns, colonization plans, the bank bill of 1864, Lincoln's policy towards the South, Jefferson Davis and the position of the southern states, Doolittle's trip through the South in 1866, relations between President Johnson and Congress, and the proposed purchase of the Virgin Islands. A few papers from his post-Senate years document national Democratic election campaigns, recollections of the 1865 congressional investigation of conditions among the Cheyenne Indians, and charges against Doolittle in 1885 by the New York Times of dishonest wartime dealing in cotton.
Correspondence in Josiah A. Noonan papers, 1834-1880.
In the John A. Dix collection, 1831-1878.
36 letters by and 8 to Doolittle (1859-1873) in various collections. Finding aid.

1863-1868. 42 items. Chiefly correspondence on Indian affairs while chairman of U.S. Senate Special Committee on Indian Affairs which conducted an investigation of relations between Indian tribes in the West and Southwest and the federal government. Finding aid.
1848-1892. Ca. 85 items. Letters received (1848-1892), and letters sent (1848-1883) relating to professional matters. Also, miscellaneous clippings and ephemera. Advance notice required.
In Alban W. Hoopes American Indian collection, 1850-1969.

1831-1893. 43 items. Correspondence with classmates and brother, Hobart College essays and orations, political and patriotic speeches, and other letters on personal affairs and early law career in Attica and Rochester.
